dialog.name: Programmer_getting_started_dlg
dialog.whatsthis: Scans the attached chain with the last used cable settings.
Creates a new blank project.
Allows the user to browse to an existing .xcf configuration file and open an existing Programmer project.
Imports the .xcf file into the current Diamond project.
Specifies the download cable type: Lattice (parallel port), USB (LSC USB cable), USB2 (FTDI USB2 cable), or Vantis.
Specifies the serial port to which the download cable is connected. Select the port from the list or click Detect Cable.
Automatically detects the parallel port to which the download cable is connected.

dialog.name: BSCAN_configuration_dlg
dialog.whatsthis: Allows you to choose one of five BSCANs configuration types: BSCAN2 4 Port, BSCAN2 8 Port Asset Model, BSCAN2 8 Port JTAG/Corelis Model, BSCAN2 12 Port JTAG/Corelis Model, or BSCAN2 16 Port JTAG/Corelis Model.
Select the scan ports for the chains you want to access.
Select RTI, run test idle, to configure the BSCAN2. Selecting TLR, test logic rest, will remove the selected ports from the configuration.
Scans the selected ports and displays the chains and devices for programming.

dialog.name: new_programmer_project_dlg
dialog.whatsthis: Create a new project from a scan with default settings.
Create a new project from a scan with custom settings.
Create a new programmer project.
Allows the user to browse to an existing Diamond project and save the Programmer project as an .xcf file.
Specifies the download cable type: Lattice (parallel port), USB (LSC USB cable), USB2 (FTDI USB2 cable), or Vantis.
Specifies the serial port to which the download cable is connected. Select the port from the list or click Detect Cable.
Automatically detects the parallel port to which the download cable is connected.

dialog.name: general_settings_dlg
dialog.whatsthis: Alllows you to select between showing the Programmer Getting Started dialog box at start-up, or opening the last Programmer proejct at start-up.
Shows the location of the Programmer log file.
Allows the user to choose in which format the USERCODE will be displayed. Choices are Hex, ASCII, and Decimal.

dialog.name: programming_settings_dlg
dialog.whatsthis: Programs all the devices on the board in parallel. If an Operation Override is selected, all Operation descriptions in the chain file are temporarily changed to the override setting.
Programs all the devices on the board one at a time. If an Operation Override is selected, all Operation descriptions in the chain file are temporarily changed to the override setting.
Uses Test-Logic-Reset (TLR) as the starting and ending JTAG state of the JTAG State Machine for download.
Avoids the Test Logic Reset State of the JTAG State Machine during download.
Specify Test-Logic-Reset (TLR) or Run-Test/Idle (RTI) as the starting and ending JTAG state of the JTAG State Machine for download.
Specify TLR or RTI as the starting JTAG state of the JTAG State Machine for download.
Specify TLR or RTI as the ending JTAG state of the JTAG State Machine for download.
Uses the fastest TCK clock speed.
Enables the Use Custome Pulse Width Delay feature.
Allows you to slow down the TCK clock. This is done by extending the low period of the clock.
Confirms that the cable signals are correctly connected to the board and devices in the JTAG chain on the board match the devices selected in the .xcf file.
Ignores any errors while downloading and continues running.

dialog.name: cable_io_settings_dlg
dialog.whatsthis: Automatically detects the parallel port to which the download cable is connected. This feature works only with a Lattice ispDOWNLOAD cable, not a Vantis cable.
Specifies the download cable type: Lattice (parallel port), USB (LSC USB cable), USB2 (FTDI USB2 cable), or Vantis.
Specifies the port to which the download cable is connected.
Specifies a custom parallel port to which the download cable is connected. Use hexadecimal format to type the port name.
Only use the four JTAG signals.
Specify additional non-JTAG signals connected to the board
Select this option if you connect the INIT pin to the download cable. This option is only available with the ispDOWNLOAD USB cable.
Select this option if you connect the DONE pin to the download cable. This option is only available with the ispDOWNLOAD USB cable.
Select this option if you connect the TRST pin to the download cable. Specify active high or active low.
Select this option if you connect the PROGRAMN pin to the download cable.
Select this option if you connect the ispEN/BSCAN pin to the download cable. Specify active high or active low.

dialog.name: device_properties_dlg
dialog.whatsthis: Selects the mode for programming the device.
Lists the available operation modes for the device. Select one from the drop-down list.
Selects the data file for programming or verify.
Specifies the TCK clock frequency for the chosen device. This value is used to determine the TCK clock period and the length of the delay times.
Select the SVF vendor for the chosen device.

Specify the instruction register length for putting the device into BYPASS during programming. The software automatically fills in this box when you select a BSDL file. You must enter the instruction register length for a JTAG-NOP device if a BSDL file is not selected.
Import the IR length from a BSDL or SVF file.
Reinitializes the device to its blank, or erased, state when a programming error occurs.
Select a custom verify mask file.
Use SVF interpreter.
Use ispVM interpeter.
Program the USERCODE register with the value in the data file.
Do not program the USERCODE register with the value in the data file. Specify a value instead.
USERCODE value (in Hex) to be programmed into the USERCODE register.
Automatically increment the USERCODE value after programming.
Amount to increment the USERCODE value after programming.
Select an external memory family from the drop-down list.
Select an external memory vendor from the drop-down list.
Select an external memory device from the drop-down list.
Select an external memory package from the drop-down list.
Select the operation mode. The default is Erase, Program, Verify.
Browse to FPGA Loader Data (.jed) file. Non-volatile devices only.
Browse to Flash Data file. Non-volatile devices only.

Displays the full file size. You can change this size by typing a different file size. This feature is useful if you only want to use a portion of the file for the operation. If you change the file size, it must be no larger than the full file size or the device size.
Displays the start address of the flash device. For the AMD parallel flash, the starting address is automatically selected and cannot be changed.
Displays the end address of the flash.
Erases the flash device if a verify error occurs.
Allows user to secure second half of SPI Flash to secure golden pattern. Available only on devices that support this secure feature.
Enter encryption key.
Confirm encryption key.
Load an encyprtion key from an external file.
Save encyrption key to external file.
Choose between ASCII or Hex key display.
Toggles display of key.
Displays the BSDL file entry name. This field is editable.
Displays pre-assigned instruction register length. Not editable.
Displays pre-assigned bypass instruction. Not editable.

dialog.name: status_register_dlg
dialog.whatsthis: Refreshes status of the device.

dialog.name: edit_io_status_dlg
dialog.whatsthis: Select the desired I/O state.

Browse to the desired .bsm file. A BSDL file, which is the acronym for Boundary Scan Description Language file, is a subset of Very High Speed IC Hardware Description Language (VHDL) that describes the boundary scan device package, pin description and boundary scan cell of the input and output pins. The BSDL file is very important in generating a boundary scan test. Without a BSDL file, it is impossible to generate any boundary scan test
Click to read I/O state. A BSDL must be selected and a device and board must be connected to the computer. Refer to the online help for more information.
The target device package.

dialog.name: edit_custom_dlg
dialog.whatsthis: Dropdown list of custom device families.
The name that was assigned to the device.
The name that was assigned to the package.
The description that was assigned to the device.

dialog.name: custom_spi_flash_dlg
dialog.whatsthis: Edit box of custom device families.
The description that was assigned to the device.
This can be any alpha-numeric string that describes the device name (for example: SPI-M25P32).
This can be any alpha-numeric string that describes the package (for example: 16-pin SOIC).
The vendor of the custom SPI Flash device.
Allows you to select device density. Available densities range from 512 Kbits to 256 Mbits.
This can be any alpha-numeric string that describes the device ID (for example: 0x15).
Allows you to choose desired bytes per sector value from dropdown.
If the SPI Flash device supports sector protection, check this box to enable protection options.

dialog.name: custom_device_information_dlg
dialog.whatsthis: Edit box limited to 12 characters maximum. Valid characters are alphanumeric and a dash.
Edit box limited to 12 characters maximum. Valid characters are alphanumeric and a dash.
This can be any alpha-numeric string that describes the package (for example: 16-pin SOIC).
ID length equal to 32, per IEEE 1149.1 Std. This box is not editable.
Limited to four hexadecimal characters. Valid characters are "Ox" followed by two hexadecimal characters. Default value is "OxFFFFFFFF".
Select any number ranging from 2 to 32.
Must be entered in binary only (0 or 1). The number of characters entered is limited to the Instruction Register Length.
Must be entered in binary only (0 or 1). The number of characters entered is limited to the Instruction Register Length.

Browse to the desired .bsm file. A BSDL file, which is the acronym for Boundary Scan Description Language file, is a subset of Very High Speed IC Hardware Description Language (VHDL) that describes the boundary scan device package, pin description and boundary scan cell of the input and output pins. The BSDL file is very important in generating a boundary scan test. Without a BSDL file, it is impossible to generate any boundary scan test.

dialog.name: cable_signal_tests_dlg
dialog.whatsthis: Alternates between log 1, logic 0, and logic 1.
Holds at logic 1.
Holds at logic 0.
(TDO Only). Reads back the data from TDO and records the read back data in the Programmer log file
Applies the selected settings to the selected pin connections. This causes the pins that have a toggle setting to toggle once from logic 1 to logic 0 to logic 1.
Performs continuous testing, causing the pins that have a toggle setting to toggle continuously until you click ESC.
Opens the log file, an ASCII text file that summarizes the results of the Cable Signal Test operations.
Tests the cable and power connections, causing the VCC Status LED to blink green or red to indicate that cable and power are detected or not detected.
Shows the status of the cable and power connection. The LED blinks green when the cable and power are detected. It blinks red and produces an error message when cable or power is not detected.
Sets the delay after each operation. Default is 0.
Sets the number of bytes read by each operation. Default is 0.

dialog.name: Deployment_Tool_getting_started_dlg
dialog.whatsthis: Choose Tester, Embedded System, or External Memory
Choose output file type. Output file types are dependent on Function Type.
Clock to open an existing Deployment Tool File (.ddt).
Dropdown list of recent Deployment Tool Files (.ddt).

dialog.name: debugger_cable_io_port_setup
dialog.whatsthis: This option is displayed when multiple cables are detected. When enabled, this option allows you to select the desired cable.
Specifies the download cable type: Lattice (parallel port), USB (LSC USB cable), or USB2 (FTDI USB2 cable).
Specifies the port to which the download cable is connected.
Specifies a custom parallel port to which the download cable is connected. Use hexadecimal format to type the port name.
This option allows you to target the slave SPI port of the selected device. This allows you to debug slave SPI device programming.
Only use the four JTAG signals.
Specify additional non-JTAG signals connected to the board
Select this option if you connect the INIT pin to the download cable. This option is only available with the ispDOWNLOAD USB cable.
Select this option if you connect the DONE pin to the download cable. This option is only available with the ispDOWNLOAD USB cable.
Select this option if you connect the TRST pin to the download cable. Specify active high or active low.
Select this option if you connect the PROGRAMN pin to the download cable.
Select this option if you connect the ispEN pin to the download cable. Specify active high or active low.

dialog.name: debugger_options
dialog.whatsthis: Allows you to specify name and location of log file.
Check to clear the log file each time Debugger is started.
Allows you to specify font, size, tab size, of Source Editor.
Toggles display of line numbers in left margin of Source Editor.
Toggles display of indicator margin in left side of Source Editor.
Disables the tool that checks the syntax of the SVF file.
Ignores the HIR, TIR, HDR, and TDR information in SVF file. If you set up HIR, TIR, HDR, or TDR in this dialog box, this option must be selected.

Continues processing the file even if there is an error. You can look at the log file for the errors encountered. When this option is selected, the log file also reports state machine transitions and delay time for debug.
Tells the Debugger that the hardware configuration is a mixed chain, therefore disabling the ISP chain when processing the SVF file.
Specifies the TCK clock frequency for the chosen SVF file. This value is used to determine the TCK clock period and the length of the delay times.
Allows you select from the following SVF vendors for the selected device: JTAG STANDARD, LATTICE, ALTERA, and XILINX. This option is available for JTAG devices only.
Sets the IR header length in number of bits (0-100).
Sets the IR trailer length in number of bits (0-100).
Sets the HDR in number of bits (0-100).
Sets the TDR in number of bits (0-100).
Ignores the HIR, TIR, HDR and TDR information in STAPL file. If you set up HIR, TIR, HDR, or TDR in this dialog box, this option must be selected.
Select the starting JTAG state of the JTAG State Machine for download. Only two states are available: TLR (Test-Logic-Reset) and RTI (Run-Test/Idle).
